tasks.task: Calibrating a manure spreader to determine application rate.
subtasks: Understand variables affecting application rates (tractor speed, gearbox settings, apron/hydraulic push gate settings).
Determine appropriate application rate based on crop/pasture needs and regulations (e.g., Minnesota's nitrogen limitation).
Choose calibration method (load area or tarp method) based on available equipment.
(For load area method) Weigh the spreader fully loaded with manure and empty, calculate manure weight.
Measure the area over which manure is spread (length x width) and convert to square feet.
Calculate application rate by dividing manure weight by area (in square feet), then multiplying by 21.8 to convert to tons per acre; repeat at least three times for accuracy.
(For tarp method) Weigh empty tarp, secure it in the spreader's path, measure tarp area, spread manure over the tarp.
Calculate manure weight per tarp, average over multiple tarps if necessary; divide by tarp area and convert to tons per acre.
Adjust speed, gearbox, or spreader gate settings if application rate is too low or high.
Determine calibration frequency (e.g., when conditions change, annually, or every couple years).

tasks.task: Using calibration results to create a manure management plan, ensuring nutrient application meets crop needs without excess.
